channel.title: openSUSE
channel.description: The openSUSE channel contains videos for and by the openSUSE community. These are educational screencasts, talks and presentations given at events and anything inbetween :-)
channel.itunes:summary: A show about the openSUSE community by the openSUSE Community. Covering all topics and subjects that have anything to do with the openSUSE project and distribution.
channel.itunes:author: The openSUSE Community

item.title: Welcome - openSUSE
item.blip:puredescription: Another year, another FOSDEM. The talk will give you a short overview what happened in the last year, what we archived within the openSUSE project.
item.description: Another year, another FOSDEM. The talk will give you a short overview what happened in the last year, what we archived within the openSUSE project.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/Ae2UAo6HCg" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="720" height="606" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed>
item.media:title: Welcome - openSUSE

item.title: openSUSE Build Service overview
item.blip:puredescription: Introduction into the openSUSE Build Service, why it was created, what are the goals it wants to achieve and a brief overview about its components.
item.description: Introduction into the openSUSE Build Service, why it was created, what are the goals it wants to achieve and a brief overview about its components.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/Ae2UAY6HCg" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="720" height="606" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed>
item.media:title: openSUSE Build Service overview

item.title: Who can you trust?
item.blip:puredescription: The openSUSE build service (obs) offers everyone the opportunity to build packages for many Linux distributions with relatively little effort. Hence the amount of available versions and variants per package is comparatively high. Therefore we need a powerful but also simple instrument to evaluate these packages, which are immediately available at the openSUSE software portal. A first approach will be an individual rating of developers working with obs.
item.description:
The openSUSE build service (obs) offers everyone the opportunity to

build packages for many Linux distributions with relatively little effort. Hence the amount of available versions and variants per package is comparatively high. Therefore we need a powerful but also simple instrument to evaluate these packages, which are immediately available at the openSUSE software portal. A first approach will be an individual rating of developers working with obs.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/Ae2SN46HCg" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="720" height="606" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed>
item.media:title: Who can you trust?

item.title: Putting the 'open' in openSUSE : Community-driven KDE development
item.blip:puredescription: The KDE team plays a central part in making openSUSE a community driven project. In this talk, the KDE team presents how it works with the community to introduce the new KDE 4 desktop to the distribution so that it meets users' needs. Recent developments in KDE and the measures taken to smooth the transition from KDE 3 are shown.
item.description:
The KDE team plays a central part in making openSUSE a community driven

project. In this talk, the KDE team presents how it works with the community to introduce the new KDE 4 desktop to the distribution so that it meets users' needs. Recent developments in KDE and the measures taken to smooth the transition from KDE 3 are shown.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/Ae2SNo6HCg" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="720" height="606" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed>
item.media:title: Putting the 'open' in openSUSE : Community-driven KDE development

item.title: Bits from your GNOME team (with build service fun inside!)
item.blip:puredescription: At the last FOSDEM, JP Rosevear gave a good overview of what was going on the GNOME land of openSUSE. It turns out that since then, many things have happened and 2008 helped the team achieve a lot. This talk will present some interesting technical changes on your desktop and how it affects the while distribution, but will also focus on the GNOME team and its processes, like for example our use of the build service.
item.description:
At the last FOSDEM, JP Rosevear gave a good overview of what was going

on the GNOME land of openSUSE. It turns out that since then, many things have happened and 2008 helped the team achieve a lot. This talk will present some interesting technical changes on your desktop and how it affects the while distribution, but will also focus on the GNOME team and its processes, like for example our use of the build service.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AezPOY6HCg" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="720" height="606" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed>
item.media:title: Bits from your GNOME team (with build service fun inside!)

item.title: Architecture of Collaboration
item.blip:puredescription: This session will focus on the “Architecture of Collaboration” implemented in the Kablink Open Collaboration project. See how the Kablink platform allows you to build applications that solve problems while encouraging collaboration among your team members. During this session an application will be developed that takes advantage of the social networking features of Kablink while solving a common teamworking problem.
item.description:
This session will focus on the “Architecture of Collaboration” implemented

in the Kablink Open Collaboration project. See how the Kablink platform allows you to build applications that solve problems while encouraging collaboration among your team members. During this session an application will be developed that takes advantage of the social networking features of Kablink while solving a common teamworking problem.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AezOSY6HCg" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="720" height="606" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed>
item.media:title: Architecture of Collaboration

item.title: openFATE - How to get your most wanted features into openSUSE
item.blip:puredescription: openSUSE opens the feature tracking process to the community. In the past, only Novell employees had access to the feature database where all features of upcoming products are tracked. Now the community can participate in the feature tracking process by requesting new features, browse existing features and contributing to them. We launched the openFATE web application (http://features.opensuse.org) shortly before FOSDEM. The talk shows how it works and explains how incoming feature requests will be handled.
item.description:
openSUSE opens the feature tracking process to the community.

In the past, only Novell employees had access to the feature database where all features of upcoming products are tracked. Now the community can participate in the feature tracking process by requesting new features, browse existing features and contributing to them. We launched the openFATE web application (http://features.opensuse.org) shortly before FOSDEM. The talk shows how it works and explains how incoming feature requests will be handled.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AezMeY6HCg" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="720" height="606" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed>
item.media:title: openFATE - How to get your most wanted features into openSUSE

item.title: YaST2 - Future Roadmap
item.blip:puredescription: openSUSE 11.0 YaST came out with new features like a themable look and a robust & fast package manager. 11.1 came out with more robust solving and various minor features. In this talk we will present all the features that have high priority for the next openSUSE release and areas where we are doing research that will eventually be features in future versions.
item.description:
openSUSE 11.0 YaST came out with new features like a themable look

and a robust & fast package manager. 11.1 came out with more robust solving and various minor features. In this talk we will present all the features that have high priority for the next openSUSE release and areas where we are doing research that will eventually be features in future versions.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AezMdo6HCg" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="720" height="606" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed>
item.media:title: YaST2 - Future Roadmap

item.title: openSUSE on Netbooks
item.blip:puredescription: Everybody loves Netbooks, so why don't use your favorite Linux distribution on it. The talks shows what the pitfalls and limitations are and how to get openSUSE working on Netbooks.
item.description:
Everybody loves Netbooks, so why don't use your favorite Linux distribution on it.

The talks shows what the pitfalls and limitations are and how to get openSUSE working on Netbooks.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AezKCY6HCg" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="720" height="606" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed>
item.media:title: openSUSE on Netbooks

item.title: MirrorBrain - Free CDN for Free Software Projects
item.blip:puredescription: The MirrorBrain, a.k.a. the openSUSE download redirector, automatically redirects clients (web browsers, download programs) to a mirror server near them. It works similar to the systems employed by sourceforge.net, mozilla.com or similar large organizations, which face a number of download requests which is too high to be practically handled by a single site. To find a mirror close to the client, the redirector "geolocates" the client by its IP address. If several mirrors are found to be suitable, the redirector load-balances requests to the mirrors based on their capabilities.
item.description: The MirrorBrain, a.k.a. the openSUSE download redirector, automatically redirects clients (web browsers, download programs) to a mirror server near them. It works similar to the systems employed by sourceforge.net, mozilla.com or similar large organizations, which face a number of download requests which is too high to be practically handled by a single site. To find a mirror close to the client, the redirector "geolocates" the client by its IP address. If several mirrors are found to be suitable, the redirector load-balances requests to the mirrors based on their capabilities.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AezJJ46HCg" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="720" height="606" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed>
item.media:title: MirrorBrain - Free CDN for Free Software Projects

item.title: Zypper - openSUSE's command line software manager
item.blip:puredescription: Zypper is a command line software management tool using the ZYpp library. It can be used to manage repositories, search for packages, install them, keep them up to date and more. This talk will highlight it's most interesting features, tips & tricks, and future plans.
item.description:
Zypper is a command line software management tool using the ZYpp

library. It can be used to manage repositories, search for packages, install them, keep them up to date and more. This talk will highlight it's most interesting features, tips & tricks, and future plans.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AeywQY6HCg" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="720" height="606" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed>
item.media:title: Zypper - openSUSE's command line software manager

item.title: openSUSE education
item.blip:puredescription: The openSUSE education project has the goal is to support schools using openSUSE, create and describe additional software-packages for educational projects and create an "add-on" CD for the regular openSUSE distribution. The talk gives you an overview about the project, where we are now and what has to be done
item.description: The openSUSE education project has the goal is to support schools using openSUSE, create and describe additional software-packages for educational projects and create an "add-on" CD for the regular openSUSE distribution. The talk gives you an overview about the project, where we are now and what has to be done
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AeysVo6HCg" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="720" height="606" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed>
item.media:title: openSUSE education

item.title: Wine - the free Windows Emulator
item.blip:puredescription: After 15 years of development Wine, the free Windows Emulator, has reached the level of completeness a 1.0 release, allowing users to now run a broad spectrum of applications between Office productivity applications, Games or speciality applications. This talk will give an introduction on how Wine works, what is possible and how it all works together, why it is not slower, why emulating only the runtime environment is to a distinct advantage compared to virtual machines.
item.description:
After 15 years of development Wine, the free Windows Emulator,

has reached the level of completeness a 1.0 release, allowing users to now run a broad spectrum of applications between Office productivity applications, Games or speciality applications. This talk will give an introduction on how Wine works, what is possible and how it all works together, why it is not slower, why emulating only the runtime environment is to a distinct advantage compared to virtual machines.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AeysHo6HCg" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="720" height="606" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed>
item.media:title: Wine - the free Windows Emulator

item.title: Legal aspects of distribution development
item.blip:puredescription: Every community distributions have to deal with legal issues. The talk shows what kind of pitfalls we have in our daily distribution work and how to solve them. This will only work with the upstream developers of the projects and most of the work will be done for every distribution again.
item.description: Every community distributions have to deal with legal issues. The talk shows what kind of pitfalls we have in our daily distribution work and how to solve them. This will only work with the upstream developers of the projects and most of the work will be done for every distribution again.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AeyQco6HCg" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="720" height="606" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed>
item.media:title: Legal aspects of distribution development

item.title: Creating customized openSUSE versions with SUSE Studio
item.blip:puredescription: SUSE Studio is a new web application to build openSUSE based appliances. It provides an easy to use interface to quickly create images for live CDs, bootable USB sticks and VMware. It's also possible to conveniently customize software selection, configuration and theming of the appliances. Third party software may be integrated through coupling with the openSUSE Build Service. Studio's testdrive feature allows users to run the appliance via the web interface for testing and further configuration.
item.description:
SUSE Studio is a new web application to build openSUSE based appliances. It

provides an easy to use interface to quickly create images for live CDs, bootable USB sticks and VMware. It's also possible to conveniently customize software selection, configuration and theming of the appliances. Third party software may be integrated through coupling with the openSUSE Build Service. Studio's testdrive feature allows users to run the appliance via the web interface for testing and further configuration.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AeyQb46HCg" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="720" height="606" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed>
item.media:title: Creating customized openSUSE versions with SUSE Studio

item.title: Create your own Linux Distribution
item.blip:puredescription: This talk will explain briefly how you create your own openSUSE based Linux distribution installation media and Live media with the openSUSE Build Service. It includes a brief introduction to kiwi-instsource (which was presented as an outlook last year) and the way we define products; how the buildservice creates an installation source from that.
item.description: This talk will explain briefly how you create your own openSUSE based Linux distribution installation media and Live media with the openSUSE Build Service. It includes a brief introduction to kiwi-instsource (which was presented as an outlook last year) and the way we define products; how the buildservice creates an installation source from that.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AeyQbY6HCg" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="720" height="606" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed>
item.media:title: Create your own Linux Distribution

item.title: Putting Cross Development Support into OBS
item.blip:puredescription: The Cross Development in OBS feature is now integrated into normal OBS development. It allows you to build, test, run applications for other processor architectures using a combination of emulators and crossbuild. Emulators are already a normal part of OBS. An analysis has been made of the different ways to implement Cross Build to result in better interoperability with existing linux distributions for other architectures. The goal was to implement Cross Development as an orthogonal feature, and to glueless implement openSUSE, Fedora, Debian, Ubuntu for embedded architektures like ARM, sh4, mips in the same way as is done already by OBS for x86 and powerpc architectures.
item.description:
The Cross Development in OBS feature is now integrated into normal OBS

development. It allows you to build, test, run applications for other processor architectures using a combination of emulators and crossbuild. Emulators are already a normal part of OBS. An analysis has been made of the different ways to implement Cross Build to result in better interoperability with existing linux distributions for other architectures. The goal was to implement Cross Development as an orthogonal feature, and to glueless implement openSUSE, Fedora, Debian, Ubuntu for embedded architektures like ARM, sh4, mips in the same way as is done already by OBS for x86 and powerpc architectures.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AeyQTI6HCg" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="720" height="606" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed>
item.media:title: Putting Cross Development Support into OBS

item.title: Collaboration in the openSUSE Build Service
item.blip:puredescription: This talk explains how to use the Collaboration features of the openSUSE Build Service. Its based on two openSUSE repositories that use them: openSUSE:Factory:Contrib and openSUSE:Factory
item.description:
This talk explains how to use the Collaboration features of

the openSUSE Build Service. Its based on two openSUSE repositories that use them: openSUSE:Factory:Contrib and openSUSE:Factory

item.media:title: Collaboration in the openSUSE Build Service

item.title: Whirlwind tour of SUSE Studio
item.blip:puredescription: In this screencast, hobbsc, takes us through SUSE Studio. He shows some of the features of Studio and creates a customised appliance for GWAVACon.

item.title: HackWeek III - OMGWTFBBQ
item.blip:puredescription: In this the last of the HackWeek III videos, we see most of the Nurenberg staff at the HackWeek BBQ. This was a spur of the moment idea, and we're very grateful to Andreas Jaeger for doing the introductions/voice over.Apologies for the background noise and also for the lack of transitions between tables of people - Kino wasn't being co-operative.
item.description:
In this the last of the HackWeek III videos, we see most of the Nurenberg staff at the HackWeek BBQ. This was a spur of the moment idea, and we're very grateful to Andreas Jaeger for doing the introductions/voice over.

Apologies for the background noise and also for the lack of transitions between tables of people - Kino wasn't being co-operative.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AdC7c46HCg" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="720" height="606" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed>
item.media:title: HackWeek III - OMGWTFBBQ

item.title: Switching A Distribution To KDE4.1.1
item.blip:puredescription: Our very own Stephan "Beineri" Binner talks at the Akedemy 08 Contributors Conference (09Aug08) about how openSUSE is moving to KDE4 as the main KDE desktop on 11.0.Many thanks to Bart Cerneels for filming and editing.
item.description:
Our very own Stephan "Beineri" Binner talks at the Akedemy 08 Contributors Conference (09Aug08) about how openSUSE is moving to KDE4 as the main KDE desktop on 11.0.

Many thanks to Bart Cerneels for filming and editing.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/Ac2AQo6HCg" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="784" height="606" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed>
item.media:title: Switching A Distribution To KDE4.1.1

item.title: HackWeek III - Nurenberg Interviews
item.blip:puredescription: This is the last episode of interviews taken in Nurenberg during HackWeek III. In this show we speak to Garrett LeSage, Flavio Costelli, Marco Mishna, Sonja Krause-Harder and Martin Lasarsch.Covering SUSE Studio, Core Services, SLE and Community.
item.description:
This is the last episode of interviews taken in Nurenberg during HackWeek III. In this show we speak to Garrett LeSage, Flavio Costelli, Marco Mishna, Sonja Krause-Harder and Martin Lasarsch.

Covering SUSE Studio, Core Services, SLE and Community.

item.title: Inkscape Primer
item.blip:puredescription: openSUSE's very own graphical maestro Jakub Steiner gives us an intro to Inkscape the Open Source vector graphics editor. This screenscast is in addition to jimmac's great presentation given to the community in openSUSE's Helping Hands session. Jakub maintains his own channel for graphical screencasts, so if anyone wants to learn more from the maestro please checkout Pixel Pusher Screencasts.
item.description:
openSUSE's very own graphical maestro Jakub Steiner gives us an intro to Inkscape the Open Source vector graphics editor. This screenscast is in addition to jimmac's great presentation given to the community in openSUSE's Helping Hands session.

Jakub maintains his own channel for graphical screencasts, so if anyone wants to learn more from the maestro please checkout Pixel Pusher Screencasts.

item.title: SUSE Rooms Nurenberg Talk05 - Who can you trust?
item.blip:puredescription: The openSUSE Build Service (oBS) offers everyone the opportunity to build packages for many Linux distributions with relatively little effort. Hence the amount of available versions and variants per package is comparatively high.Therefore we need a powerful but also simple instrument to evaluate these packages, which are immediately available at the openSUSE software portal. A first approach will be a user contributed rating of all developers working with obs. Marko Jung takes us through the trust system for the oBS
item.description:
The openSUSE Build Service (oBS) offers everyone the opportunity to build packages for many Linux distributions with relatively little effort. Hence the amount of available versions and variants per package is comparatively high.

Therefore we need a powerful but also simple instrument to evaluate these packages, which are immediately available at the openSUSE software portal. A first approach will be a user contributed rating of all developers working with obs.

Marko Jung takes us through the trust system for the oBS

item.title: SUSE Rooms Nurenberg Talk03 - Content Distribution On Large Scale

item.title: FOSDEM08 Day02 Talk11 - Desktop accessibility & UI Automation
item.blip:puredescription: Accessibility is a hot topic, as is interoperability. Michael Meeks talks about how we will bring the new UI Automation API to openSUSE, allowing Mono/Winforms apps to run un-modified on Linux, the differences in the APIs, and the various challenges here.
item.description:
Accessibility is a hot topic, as is interoperability.

Michael Meeks talks about how we will bring the new UI Automation API to openSUSE, allowing Mono/Winforms apps to run un-modified on Linux, the differences in the APIs, and the various challenges here.

item.title: FOSDEM08 Day02 Talk10 - mod_zrkadlo the openSUSE redirector
item.blip:puredescription: Peter Poemel takes us through scaling a download infrastructure with success. Increasing popularity leads to technical challenges. He describes how the openSUSE infrastructure serves millions of download requests, employing a system of mirrors and mod_zrkadlo, a redirection module for the Apache HTTP server. Peter talks about the backgrounds of redirection using IP geolocation, functioning of the redirector, its implementation and how to use it. He also shows how to deal with mirrors which may be out of date, incomplete, or unreliable.
item.description:
Peter Poemel takes us through scaling a download infrastructure with success.

Increasing popularity leads to technical challenges. He describes how the openSUSE infrastructure serves millions of download requests, employing a system of mirrors and mod_zrkadlo, a redirection module for the Apache HTTP server. Peter talks about the backgrounds of redirection using IP geolocation, functioning of the redirector, its implementation and how to use it. He also shows how to deal with mirrors which may be out of date, incomplete, or unreliable.
item.media:title: FOSDEM08 Day02 Talk10 - mod_zrkadlo the openSUSE redirector

item.title: FOSDEM08 Day02 Talk09 - One Click Install: What it is, How to Leverage it, and Future Improvements.
item.blip:puredescription: A new feature known as "One Click Install" was introduced in openSUSE 10.3, this helped improve the user experience of locating and installing software. Benjamin Weber, the creator of openSUSE's "One Click" will explain the reasons for the technology, how it works, and demonstrate some current and future uses within the openSUSE project. It will be shown how software vendors can utilise the technology to make it easier for users to install their software. Additionally some of the problems that have become apparant during the last few months, and their solutions will be explored
item.description:
A new feature known as "One Click Install" was introduced in openSUSE 10.3, this helped improve the user experience of locating and installing software.

Benjamin Weber, the creator of openSUSE's "One Click" will explain the reasons for the technology, how it works, and demonstrate some current and future uses within the openSUSE project. It will be shown how software vendors can utilise the technology to make it easier for users to install their software. Additionally some of the problems that have become apparant during the last few months, and their solutions will be explored
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AciLTY6HCg" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="1024" height="606" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed>
item.media:title: FOSDEM08 Day02 Talk09 - One Click Install: What it is, How to Leverage it, and Future Improvements.

item.title: FOSDEM08 Day02 Talk08 - The New Solver
item.blip:puredescription: Michael Schroeder takes us through the SatSolver used by zypper. The solver used in openSUSE 10.3 was rewritten from scratch. It is based on standard SAT algorithms (boolean satusfiability problem) and supports new features like OR dependencies. Plus, it is much faster than the old approch and presents the user with sensible suggestions if a conflicts are found.
item.description: Michael Schroeder takes us through the SatSolver used by zypper. The solver used in openSUSE 10.3 was rewritten from scratch. It is based on standard SAT algorithms (boolean satusfiability problem) and supports new features like OR dependencies. Plus, it is much faster than the old approch and presents the user with sensible suggestions if a conflicts are found.

item.title: How to use rpm2git
item.blip:puredescription: In a follow on to Federico's Introduction To rpm2git, he takes you through how to use the tool.
item.description: In a follow on to Federico's Introduction To rpm2git, he takes you through how to use the tool.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AcbzdI6HCg" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="928" height="702" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed>
item.media:title: How to use rpm2git

item.title: Federico Mena Quintero introduces you to rpm2git
item.blip:puredescription: Various GNU/Linux distros have developed different, ad-hoc ways of publishing the patches they put on top of "pristine" released tarballs from upstream projects like GNOME. openSUSE lets you download full SRPMS from an FTP site, or in a slower but more elegant way through the openSUSE Build Service. Fedora has a CVS repository where they put specfiles and patches. Back in the Ximian days, we had a pretty cute web page, patches.ximian.com, where you could ask for the patches for a specific module, for one or more distros. Since every distro publishes its patches in a different way, the following happens. First, upstream developers have a hard time actually looking for those patches to review them and see if they are fit for inclusion in the mainline releases. Where does $distro publish its stuff? How do I know what its latest version is? How do I know what bugs they were trying to fix? Upstream developers should not have to learn the idiosyncrasies of each distro just to get code from them. Second, distros themselves end up doing a lot of duplicated work. I just found out that both Fedora and openSUSE have patches in their gtk package to do the same things: one for GtkEntry to change the "*" into a "●" when the entry is being used for password entry; another one to let 64-bit builds install the 32-bit and 64-bit libraries in the correct places. If there had been an easy way to share those patches, maybe they wouldn't have duplicated the same work. I am pleased to give you rpm2git. This is a little tool that you can use as follows: First, you get a Git clone of an upstream repository, for example, something out of git-mirror.gnome.org. Second, you get a SRPM and unpack it. You look at the version of that package (say, Nautilus 2.22.2). Third, you find the Git tag for that version (svn/NAUTILUS_2_22_2). Fourth, you call rpm2git with that tag name, your specfile, and a destination branch name. Rpm2git will create a branch starting at the tag you specified, and it will apply the patches from the SRPM as individual commits. The commit messages come from the patch comments. The idea is that you can later just publish this Git repository, and upstream developers or other distros will be able fetch your branches into their own base repositories. Then, they can cherry-pick patches at their convenience.
item.description:
Various GNU/Linux distros have developed different, ad-hoc ways of publishing the patches they put on top of "pristine" released tarballs from upstream projects like GNOME. openSUSE lets you download full SRPMS from an FTP site, or in a slower but more elegant way through the openSUSE Build Service. Fedora has a CVS repository where they put specfiles and patches. Back in the Ximian days, we had a pretty cute web page, patches.ximian.com, where you could ask for the patches for a specific module, for one or more distros.

Since every distro publishes its patches in a different way, the following happens.

First, upstream developers have a hard time actually looking for those patches to review them and see if they are fit for inclusion in the mainline releases. Where does $distro publish its stuff? How do I know what its latest version is? How do I know what bugs they were trying to fix? Upstream developers should not have to learn the idiosyncrasies of each distro just to get code from them.

Second, distros themselves end up doing a lot of duplicated work. I just found out that both Fedora and openSUSE have patches in their gtk package to do the same things: one for GtkEntry to change the "*" into a "●" when the entry is being used for password entry; another one to let 64-bit builds install the 32-bit and 64-bit libraries in the correct places. If there had been an easy way to share those patches, maybe they wouldn't have duplicated the same work.

I am pleased to give you rpm2git. This is a little tool that you can use as follows:

First, you get a Git clone of an upstream repository, for example, something out of git-mirror.gnome.org.

Second, you get a SRPM and unpack it. You look at the version of that package (say, Nautilus 2.22.2).

Third, you find the Git tag for that version (svn/NAUTILUS_2_22_2).

Fourth, you call rpm2git with that tag name, your specfile, and a destination branch name.

Rpm2git will create a branch starting at the tag you specified, and it will apply the patches from the SRPM as individual commits. The commit messages come from the patch comments.

The idea is that you can later just publish this Git repository, and upstream developers or other distros will be able fetch your branches into their own base repositories. Then, they can cherry-pick patches at their convenience.
item.media:player: <embed src="http://blip.tv/play/AcbyQI6HCg" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="832" height="654" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true"></embed>
item.media:title: Federico Mena Quintero introduces you to rpm2git
